node.title: All three men were convicted of murdering Ahmaud Arbery, but only one was convicted of ‘malice murder.’
node.alt: Travis McMichael testifies as he is cross-examined by prosecutor Linda Dunikoski.
node.description: In finding Travis McMichael guilty of that charge, the twelve jurors found that he had deliberately intended to kill Mr. Arbery.
node.content: ["A jury found three men guilty of murder on Wednesday in the killing of Ahmaud Arbery, but though all defendants were facing a charge of \u201cmalice murder,\u201d only one man, Travis McMichael, was convicted on that charge.", "In finding Mr. McMichael, the man who fatally shot Mr. Arbery in February 2020, guilty of that charge, the twelve jurors found that he had deliberately intended to kill Mr. Arbery. ", "The jury acquitted Travis McMichael's father, Gregory McMichael, as well as their neighbor, William Bryan, on that charge, suggesting that they did not believe either man intended to kill Mr. Arbery. But jurors still found both men guilty of murder under Georgia\u2019s \u201cfelony murder\u201d statute, which allows a person to be convicted of murder if the person causes someone\u2019s death while committing another felony.", "Both malice murder and felony murder carry the same maximum penalty \u2014 up to life in prison, in this case \u2014 so the jury\u2019s acquittal of Gregory McMichael and Mr. Bryan on malice murder is unlikely to impact their prison term.", "Sarah Gerwig-Moore, a professor at Mercer University School of Law, in Macon, Ga., said that without hearing from the jurors themselves, it is difficult to know their reasons for only finding Travis McMichael guilty of malice murder.", "\u201cIt\u2019s hard to read those tea leaves,\u201d Ms. Gerwig-Moore said, adding, \u201cBecause Travis McMichael was the man who shot Ahmaud Arbery, there\u2019s a chance that the jury could have seen him as the primary aggressor, and that may be one way there\u2019s that distinction in guilt.\u201d"]
